content.title: Jobs with cats: from vets to kitten socialisers and more - The Telegraph
content.desc: The National Cat Adoption Centre is a remarkable place for many reasons: not least, that it’s the biggest centre for rescued cats in the United Kingdom. The centre has many employees, working with cats in different ways. Three of the more intriguing “cat jobs” are a dedicated in-house vet, volunteer kitten socialisers and volunteer cat desensitisers. To find out what these roles involve, read on. In-house veterinary surgeon A vet working in a cat adoption centre may seem like an obvious niche, but in fact one of the unusual aspects of the centre is that it has its own dedicated in-house vet...

content.title: Claws come out on Twitter after footage of woman striking & robbing stray cat goes viral (VIDEO) - RT
content.desc: A Turkish woman has come under fire after footage of her stealing a blanket from a stray cat before striking the animal with it went viral. People took to Twitter to brand her a “brutal thief.” The footage shows the white cat hanging around on the side of a street next to a cardboard box, supposedly the feline’s home, where the stray animal used to sleep and keep warm in chilling temperatures. The box contained a tiny coloured blanket. A woman in a grey coat passes the cat and affectionately pats him on the head before moving on. content.title: How pets improve mental health issues, from depression to PTSD - The Independent
content.desc: The comforting padding of feet across the otherwise silent house, the welcoming nudge of wet nose on arm and the soothing sense of unconditional love can make lives tainted by mental health more bearable. Formerly love-deprived Nell, my rescue spaniel, loves her cuddles, and she “asks” for them on a daily basis. The strength of her unconditional and innocent sense of love is palpable and we both derive comfort and a sense of calm from that closeness. Just by stroking, sitting next to or playing with a pet can help to relax and calm someone with a mental health condition. Dogs especially wil...

content.title: The stunning national park where the painted wolves of Dynasties roam - The Telegraph
content.desc: A trio of celebrated species - lions, emperor penguins and chimpanzees - starred in the first three episodes of David Attenborough’s Dynasties. Last night’s show, however, focused on a little-known creature: the African wild dog, or painted wolf. Unfamiliar they may be, but the plight of these animals was still utterly gripping, a family feud akin to Game of Thrones in which two packs - one led by alpha-female Tate, the other by her daughter, Blacktip - fought over territory while dodging lions, crocodiles and hyenas. “Two years in the making, this was a superb piece of filmmaking, offering...
